newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: FALLING BED SALES SHOW S.AFRICAN TOURISM FLAGGING.
newsitem.headline: FALLING BED SALES SHOW S.AFRICAN TOURISM FLAGGING.

text.p: South Africa's tourist boom is flagging, with Johannesburg in particular being shunned by visitors fearful of the country's notorious crime rate, according to new figures published on Tuesday.
Hotel bednights sold to foreign tourists declined by 6.3 percent in August from the same month last year to 182,686, the Central Statistical Service said.
The Johannesburg tourism region suffered the most with its share of the national market dwindling to 11 percent from 20 percent a year ago.
Cape Town and the surrounding Winelands remain the most popular destination, accounting for 26.3 percent of bednights sold.

South Africa's tourist industry was kick-started by the first all-race elections in 1994 and last year tourist arrivals jumped by 50 percent to 1.1 million. But further growth has been stymied by mounting fears over crime.

While most holiday-makers have no trouble, police figures show South Africa is one of the world's most crime-ridden societies. A total of 1.98 million serious crimes were reported last year, with only half solved, including 36,888 rapes, 18,983 murders and 66,838 armed robberies.
